pageProps.body:
Heat Equation

The heat equation, or the diffusion equation, models the conduction of heat throughout a solid (in one dimension only, though it is possible to generalize to more dimensions).

To understand it, let us consider the case of a 1D metal rod with zero (or negligible) thickness, and some length LLL. Let the temperature of the rod at any given point xxx along the rod at a time ttt be T(x,t)T(x,t)T(x,t), such that T(x,0)T(x,0)T(x,0) describes the temperature distribution of the rod at time t=0t=0t=0, T(x,1)T(x,1)T(x,1) at t=1t=1t=1, and so on:

At time t0t_0t0​, every point on the rod has a temperature T(x)T(x)T(x), and the value of T(x)T(x)T(x) is expressed on the plot above. If we combine such plots for every value of ttt, we obtain something as follows:

Intuition tells us that as time elapses, the graph will "flatten out" (as shown above); heat will disperse evenly throughout the rod. If we can codify that sense of intuition into the language of differential equations, we'll have our heat equation.

To do that, let's consider a discrete, rather than continuous, version of the rod. Say, for instance, that we are measuring the temperature of the rod at ten distinct points:

Let's consider only the behavior of a single point:

On the left-hand case, the point x2x_2x2​ has a higher temperature than both of its neighbors x1x_1x1​ and x3x_3x3​, telling us that its temperature will tend to decrease; on the right-hand case, though x1x_1x1​ has a higher temperature than x2x_2x2​ and x3x_3x3​ has lower, the average of x1x_1x1​ and x3x_3x3​ still exceeds x3x_3x3​, making it tend to increase in temperature.

Thus, we can write that for a discrete point x2x_2x2​ on the rod with temperature T(x2,t)T(x_2,t)T(x2​,t), the rate of change of its temperature is proportional to the average of its temperature difference with its neighboring points:

∂T∂t=α((T3−T2)−(T2−T1)2)\frac{\partial T}{\partial t} = \alpha(\frac{(T_3-T_2)-(T_2-T_1)}{2})∂t∂T​=α(2(T3​−T2​)−(T2​−T1​)​)

for a certain proportionality constant α\alphaα. (T3−T2)−(T2−T1)=ΔT2−ΔT1=ΔΔT1(T_3-T_2)-(T_2-T_1) = \Delta T_2 - \Delta T_1 = \Delta \Delta T_1(T3​−T2​)−(T2​−T1​)=ΔT2​−ΔT1​=ΔΔT1​, the second difference of T1T_1T1​; as the distance between neighboring points becomes infinitesimal, the second difference is analogous to the second derivative with respect to xxx. Thus, we obtain the heat equation:

∂T∂t=κ∂2T∂x2\frac{\partial T}{\partial t}=\kappa \frac{\partial^2 T}{\partial x^2}∂t∂T​=κ∂x2∂2T​

where κ\kappaκ is the diffusivity of the rod.

Solutions to the heat equation lie once again in the method of changing variables from (x,t)(x,t)(x,t) to a single variable η\etaη such that the function TTT can be rewritten entirely in terms of η\etaη: T(x,t)=T(η)T(x,t)=T(\eta)T(x,t)=T(η).

Note that this is the same method we used with solving the transport equation, where we had x=x0+ctx = x_0 + ctx=x0​+ct which yielded a function entirely in ttt. The question is, what is η\etaη?

Unlike the transport equation, there are many, many different possible ways to define η\etaη as some function of ttt and xxx such that it helps us solve the heat equation, so let us consider only one:

η=x2κt\eta = \frac{x}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}}η=2κt​x​

where κ\kappaκ is again the diffusivity. This is known as a similarity solution, as it only encompasses all solutions which are in exactly this form (can be written in terms of η\etaη) and are similar to one another.

If we posit that T(x,t)T(x,t)T(x,t) can be written entirely as T(η(x,t))=F(η)T(\eta(x,t))=F(\eta)T(η(x,t))=F(η), a single-variable function of η\etaη, then we have

{∂T∂x=∂F∂η∂η∂x∂T∂t=∂F∂η∂η∂t\begin{cases} \frac{\partial T}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial x} \\ \frac{\partial T}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial t} \end{cases}{∂x∂T​=∂η∂F​∂x∂η​∂t∂T​=∂η∂F​∂t∂η​​

and with η=x2κt\eta = \frac{x}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}}η=2κt​x​, we have

{∂η∂x=12κt∂η∂t=−κx4(κt)−32\begin{cases} \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial x} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}} \\ \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial t} = -\frac{\kappa x}{4}(\kappa t)^{-\frac{3}{2}} \end{cases}{∂x∂η​=2κt​1​∂t∂η​=−4κx​(κt)−23​​

resulting in

{∂T∂x=12κt∂F∂η∂2T∂x2=12κt∂2F∂η2∂η∂x=14κt∂2F∂η2∂T∂t=∂F∂η∂η∂t=−κx4(κt)−32∂F∂η=−12x2κtt∂F∂η=−η2t∂F∂η\begin{cases} \frac{\partial T}{\partial x} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}}\frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} \\ \frac{\partial^2 T}{\partial x^2} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}}\frac{\partial^2 F}{\partial \eta^2} \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial x} = \frac{1}{4\kappa t}\frac{\partial^2 F}{\partial \eta^2} \\ \frac{\partial T}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial \eta}{\partial t} = -\frac{\kappa x}{4}(\kappa t)^{-\frac{3}{2}}\frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} = -\frac{1}{2}\frac{x}{2\sqrt{\kappa t}t}\frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} = -\frac{\eta}{2t}\frac{\partial F}{\partial \eta} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​∂x∂T​=2κt​1​∂η∂F​∂x2∂2T​=2κt​1​∂η2∂2F​∂x∂η​=4κt1​∂η2∂2F​∂t∂T​=∂η∂F​∂t∂η​=−4κx​(κt)−23​∂η∂F​=−21​2κt​tx​∂η∂F​=−2tη​∂η∂F​​

Substituting this into the original heat equation yields

−η2tdFdη=14td2Fdη2d2Fdη2+2ηdFdη=0\begin{aligned} -\frac{\eta}{2t}\frac{dF}{d\eta}&=\frac{1}{4t}\frac{d^2F}{d\eta^2} \\ \frac{d^2F}{d\eta^2}+2\eta\frac{dF}{d\eta}=0 \end{aligned}−2tη​dηdF​dη2d2F​+2ηdηdF​=0​=4t1​dη2d2F​

which solves to obtain dFdη=Ae−η2\frac{dF}{d\eta} = Ae^{-\eta^2}dηdF​=Ae−η2 and thus the non-elementary F=α erf(η)+βF=\alpha\ \text{erf}(\eta) + \betaF=α erf(η)+β for the error function erf, defined as

erf(η)=2π∫0ηe−u2 du\text{erf}(\eta)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\int_{0}^{\eta}e^{-u^2}\ duerf(η)=π​2​∫0η​e−u2 du

Fin!
